CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Procedural aspect);Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial
JUDGES: András Sajó;Françoise Tulkens;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Nona Tsotsoria;Vladimiro Zagrebelsky
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested by the gendarmerie in the border city of GPE on her return from GPE . She was detained in a gendarmerie station . According to an arrest report prepared by the gendarmerie DATE , the applicant was informed of her right to be represented by a lawyer and to inform her family about her arrest . Nevertheless , it was also stated in the same document that , if the offence in respect of which she was arrested fell within the jurisdiction of ORG , she could consult a lawyer only if her detention period was extended by a judge or if a judge ordered her detention in a prison . The applicant signed the report and wrote on it that she had “ no requests ” .

CARDINAL . The applicant was interrogated during her detention at the gendarmerie station , and an CARDINAL - page statement was taken from her between DATE . In her statement the applicant admitted to having engaged in activities on behalf of the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by a doctor at the Edirne branch of ORG . According to the medical report drawn up DATE , there were “ no injuries or signs of ill - treatment on her body ” .

CARDINAL . DATE she was brought before the prosecutor and then before ORG , which ordered her pre - trial detention in prison . In CARDINAL statements made during meetings with the prosecutor and the judge the applicant admitted to being a member of the ORG .
CARDINAL . According to the CARDINAL statements referred to above , the applicant did not want to be represented by a lawyer during the questioning .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor at ORG filed an indictment against the applicant with that court for the offence of membership of an illegal organisation , namely the ORG . The prosecutor , referring to the above - mentioned statements made by the applicant , alleged that the applicant had left GPE in DATE and had been taken to the ORG 's training camp in Lavrion , GPE , where she had received training . Following her training she had obtained a false NORP passport in order to enter the GPE . During her time in LOC she had engaged in activities on behalf of the ORG in GPE and the GPE .
CARDINAL . Criminal proceedings against the applicant commenced before ORG ( hereafter “ the trial court ” ) . During the proceedings the applicant was represented by a lawyer .

CARDINAL . During the first hearing , which was held on DATE , the applicant rejected the allegations against her and alleged that , before she was brought before the prosecutor and the judge on DATE , she had been told by the gendarmes that if she did not accept the accusations before the judge and the prosecutor she would be taken back to the gendarmerie station and tortured again . That had been the reason she had accepted the accusations before the prosecutor and the judge . When asked by the trial court what she had to say about the medical report of CARDINAL DATE in which it was stated that her body bore no signs of ill - treatment , the applicant replied that the medical report had been prepared before she was beaten up by gendarme officers and threatened with rape . She also alleged that she had been stripped naked by the gendarmes during her detention . The applicant further informed the trial court that the gendarmes had not asked her whether she wanted to be represented by a lawyer during the questioning .

CARDINAL . During the second hearing , which was held on DATE , the applicant submitted a handwritten letter to the trial court . In the letter she alleged , in particular , that while she was being detained in the gendarmerie station she had been insulted by gendarme officers , blindfolded , beaten up and drenched with water . Before being questioned she had been undressed and “ they ” had touched various parts of her body . Threats of rape and death , directed at her and her mother , had also been made .

CARDINAL . The lawyer representing the applicant told the trial court that his client 's questioning had been in breach of the applicable procedure and legislation and , as such , the statements taken from her constituted unlawfully obtained evidence which was not admissible in a court of law . Other than the statements taken from his client by the gendarmerie and then by the prosecutor and the judge on DATE , there was no evidence against her . The lawyer drew the trial court 's attention to a ORG decision according to which confessions not supported by further evidence were not admissible as evidence .

CARDINAL . NORP The lawyer further asked the trial court to hear a “ cassette of the questioning ” of the applicant which had apparently been mentioned in a document drawn up by the gendarmerie . This request was rejected by the trial court which noted that the cassette was not in its possession .
CARDINAL . The lawyer also pointed out that there was no mention of his client 's name in the statements taken from ORG who , according to the indictment , had helped his client to go to GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was found guilty as charged and sentenced to DATE imprisonment . In convicting the applicant the trial court had regard to the statements taken from her at the gendarmerie station and then by the prosecutor and the judge on DATE , as well as to the statements made by ORG in the course of his trial in DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against her conviction and argued , in particular , that the decision of the trial court had not been adequately reasoned . In the grounds of appeal the applicant 's lawyer also repeated his earlier defence submissions concerning the allegedly unlawful nature of the evidence used in convicting his client , and referred to various Articles of the Convention .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the applicant 's conviction .

CARDINAL . At the time notice of the application was given to the respondent Government , the Government were requested to submit to the ORG a copy of the “ cassette of questioning ” referred to above ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . It appears from the documents submitted to the ORG by the applicant that ORG requested ORG to obtain the cassette so that it could be submitted to ORG . The gendarmerie , who were requested by the domestic judicial authorities to produce the cassette , stated in their letter of CARDINAL DATE that they had “ no records of the cassette being handed over to the PERSON prosecutor ” .
